stem: A 43-year-old female presents with 'attacks' of intense headaches, heart pounding, and severe sweating. Based on the documentation in the Endocrine Secondary Hypertension Evaluation tab, complete the bowtie by selecting the most likely condition, the two actions the nurse should take, and the two parameters the nurse should monitor.

tabs.title: SBAR
tabs.content:
Situation: Investigation of episodic hypertensive crises.
Background: Occur during exercise or times of stress. No prior history of hypertension.
Assessment: Client is currently experiencing an 'attack.' She is tremulous and reporting a 'pounding' sensation in her chest.
Recommendation: 24-hour VMA and metanephrine urine collection.

actionOptions.text: Avoid all vigorous activity and provide a quiet environment
Instruct the client to NOT palpate the abdomen
Administer high-dose Beta-blockers as the FIRST-line drug

rationale.correct: The client presents with the classic triad of Pheochromocytoma (c2): Headache, Pounding heart (Palpitations), and Perspiration (Sweating), along with severe episodic hypertension. The normal thyroid labs rule out Thyroid Storm. Priority actions: Prevent 'attacks' by avoiding triggers like stress/activity (a1) and NEVER PALPATING THE ABDOMEN (a2), as pressure on the tumor can cause a massive catecholamine dump. Monitoring BP (p1) and neurological symptoms (p2) is vital.
clinicalPearls: Pheochromocytoma is a tumor of the adrenal medulla that secretes catecholamines (Epinephrine/Norepinephrine).
Medication sequence: Alpha-blockers (Phenoxybenzamine) MUST be given BEFORE Beta-blockers to prevent unopposed alpha-vasoconstriction and dangerous BP spikes.
The 5 H's of Pheo: Hypertension, Headache, Hyperhidrosis (sweat), Hypermetabolism, Hyperglycemia.

questionTrap.trap: Beginning beta-blockers immediately for the high heart rate.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Incorrect in Pheo! You must block the Alpha receptors first. If you block the beta-vessels only, the alpha-vessels will constrict so hard the patient might have a stroke.

mnemonic.title: PHE-Five
mnemonic.expansion: P-Palpitations. H-Headache. E-Episodic. F-Flash of perspiration. I-Increased BP. V-VMA urine test. E-Empty (Don't palpate) abdomen.
